learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate understanding of and ability to apply relevant practices and protocols in inter-cultural music making.
Demonstrate capacity to create music in inter-cultural contexts, through collaborative, compositional and/or improvisational skills.
Demonstrate skills in communication, creativity and networking in the context of curated music events and opportunities.
Understand and critically reflect on concepts and issues relevant to inter-cultural music making.
Understand the role and value of diverse voices and backgrounds within the music industry.

assessments.task_description:
Students will make contributions to a forum/discussion board through the MUSC3910 Blackboard site, with a minimum of three posts in stages including (1) at the start of the course, (2) mid-way through the course, and (3) near the end of the course. The purpose will be to record students' initial ideas about the meanings of inter-cultural music making, what they understand it to be, how they feel they are equiped to make music in this context, and what their expectations are. Their posts and those of others in the class will help students to track their understanding and engagement with inter-cultural music making, its practices and concepts as they navigate the course. Student posts will be available across the course members for others too read and share ideas.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students may be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Discussion posts will be logged in the relevant item in the MUSC3910 Blackboard site
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students will create a pitch for a performance in a curated music festival, drawing on ideas and concepts related to inter-cultural music making. Their pitch will show awareness of the protocols and sensitivities around inter-cultural music making and performance curation, effective communication strategies and use of relevant media. Students will be given access to real-life models which will inform the creation and design of their pitch.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students may be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will submit their pitch through the relevant submission link in the MUSC3910 Blackboard site. It will include both video of the pitch and supporting material (e.g. slide deck).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
9/02/2026 - 13/02/2026

Scheduling for the presentation of creative work will be organised during the semester. It will take place during exam week. Under certain circumstances it may be subject to alteration by mutual agreement.
assessments.task_description:
Students will take part in a creative output which is the outcome of their work during the collaborative sessions throughout the course. This can be in the form of a composition or (fully or partially) improvised performance, it may be done individually or as part of a mutually agreed group. The evaluation of the creative output will focus primarily on how it reflects the development of knowledge and skills in inter-cultural music making developed over the semester, rather than on particular technical standards.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 8(01 Dec - 01 Feb)
learning_activities.topic:
Workshop

A two-hour weekly class during while students will participate in a range of practical music making activities, discussion and creative work.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
